titleInfo.title: The Childcare Handbook: Needs, Programs & Possibilities

location.physicalLocation: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

mods.abstract: This document explains the Comprehensive Child Development Act of 1971, which was vetoed by President Richard Nixon. Part I, "Who Needs Child Care," documents a range of pressing social and economic forces and everyday personal crises that contribute to a growing majority of families' being likely to need child care services at some point to help them stay intact. Part II, "Program Profiles," highlights several model child care programs such as the After School Day Care Association, Inc. in Madison, Wisconsin; the A.P. Beutel II Day Care Center in Freeport, TX; and the Child Care Resource and Referral, Inc. in Rochester, Minnesota. Part III draws further upon the accumulated experience of workshop participants to spell out what advocates can do in both immediate and the longer range to protect and expand existing local and national child care programs that are working.

It is intended to serve as a supplement to State Developments in Child Care, Early Education, and School-Age Care 2001; State Developments in Child Care and Early Education 1999; State Child Care and Early Education Developments; Highlights and Updates for 1998; and State Developments in Child Care and Early Education 1997.Children's Defense Fund2001reportsreformatted digital engtext Blank, HelenAuthor Behr, AndreasAuthor Schulman, KarenAuthor

This information was collected through phone interviews with experts in each state.Children's Defense Fund1997reportsreformatted digital engtext Blank, HelenAuthor Adams, GinaAuthor

0116_000050_000335State Child Care and Early Education Developments: Highlights and Updates for 1998Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report is one of a series of reports by CDF concerning state policies and practices in child care and education. The report provides highlights and updates regarding state actions on child care and early education issues during 1998. The report is intended to serve as a supplement and companion to the more comprehensive information presented in State Developments in Child Care and Early Education 1997. The information in the report was collected through written surveys and phone interviews with advocates in each state. The final draft was reviewed for verification by advocates and state child care administrators in each state.Children's Defense Fund1999Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Blank, HelenAuthor Poersch, NicoleAuthor

0116_000050_000336The Health Insurance Crisis for America's ChildrenLangston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)The information presented in this report documents research conducted over a decade demonstrating the poor state of America's maternal and child health. 0116_000050_000339An Opinion Maker's Guide to Children in Election Year 1992938008900Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report highlights how the USA measures up in world rank in the areas of infant mortality, mortality for children under five years of age, low birthweight babies, proportion of one-year olds fully immunized, number of school-age children per teacher, math achievement of 8th grade students, expenditures on elementary and secondary eduction, teen pregnancy rates, and childhood poverty rates. The spending priorities made by Congress and what the priority agenda for 1992 should look like to ensure that children and families receive the support they need is closely studied.Children's Defense Fund1991Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)Author

0116_000050_000340Key Facts about Child Care and Early Education: A Briefing BookLangston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This briefing book on child care and early education includes factsheets on a range of child care and early education issues. If includes basic facts about child care and early education, their importance to children, families, abd communities, some of the challenges facing families who need child care and early education, and information on key child care and early education policies and programs. A series of factsheets on the importance of good quality care, the importance of child care to help families work, the inadequacy of the supply of care, and a list of the various programs and policies that help families understand the roles played by federal, state, and local governments as well as private and public sectors. 50-state date, including maternal labor force participation, the number of regulated child care settings, the percent of schools offering extended day programs, selected child care licensing regulations, preschool participation rates of poor children, state rankings on financial commitment to child care and early education, the number of children participating in the Child and Adult Health Food Program (CACFP), and the number of children participating in Head Start are also included.Children's Defense Fund1997Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Adams, GinaAuthor Poersch, NicoleAuthor

0116_000050_000341Key Facts: Essential Information about Child Care, Early Education, and School-Age CareLangston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This briefing book includes a series of fact sheets concerning child care, early education, and school-age care, as well as information on major child care, early education, and school-age policies and programs. The fact sheets make a compelling case for investing in efforts to help children and families overcome the myriad child care, early education, and school-age challenges they face each day so they can get the quality early learning and after-school experiences they need to succeed.Children's Defense Fund1999Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Blank, HelenAuthor Schulman, KarenAuthor Ewen, DanielleAuthor

0116_000050_000342Children and Federal Health Care Cuts: A National Survey of the Impact of Federal Health Budget Reductions on State Maternal and Child Health Services During 1982Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)To determine whether the Reagan Administration's claim that Fiscal Year 1982 budget cuts would reduce only duplicative and wasteful services and not affect the truly needy, CDF initiated a national survey of changes in state maternal and child health services in 49 states (Nebraska did not respond to the Title V portion of CDF's survey) and the District of Columbia to assess the FY 1982 budget cuts' effects on children and families. The survey focused on Medicaid, the Title V Maternal and Child Health Block Grant, and the Community Health Centers Program because they represent the largest sources of federal health funds for mothers and children, are interdependent, and are the health care "providers of last resort" for the poor. The disturbing findings of this survey are included in this report.Children's Defense Fund1983reportsreformatted digital engtext Rosenbaum, SaraAuthor Weitz, JudithAuthor

0116_000050_000344A Fragile Foundation: State Child Care Assistance PoliciesLangston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report is one of a series of reports by CDF concerning child care and early education. It examines state policies concerning important features of each state's child care assistance programs. Topics covered are who is able to receive assistance , how easy it is for them to access assistance, how much parents must contribute towards the cost of care, how much providers who serve children receiving assistance are reimbursed, how providers are paid, and how states administer their programs. Section topics are Income Eligibility Criteria, Availability and Accessibility of Assistance, Maintaining Eligibility, Parent Fees, Reimbursement Rates, Differential Rates, Payment Processes, Contracts and Certificates, Special Populations, and Comparison of 1995 and 2000 Policies.Children's Defense Fund2001reportsreformatted digital engtext Schulman, KarenAuthor Blank, HelenAuthor Ewen, DanielleAuthor

0116_000050_000345Decade of Indifference: Maternal and Child Health Trends 1980-1990Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report assesses the progress made by the US between 1980 and 1990 in reaching maternal and child health objectives set by the US Surgeon General in 1978. The report concludes that the US failed dismally to reach these key goals. As a result, many American babies needlessly died or became disabled. The report states that the health of pregnant women and infants in the US got worse as a result of the failure of seven of eight key indicators.Children's Defense Fund1993Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)Author

0116_000050_000346The Family Support Act: How Can It Help Teen Parents?Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This booklet was created to help teen parent service providers get involved with the Family Support Act (FSA) of 1988, which targeted new education and training efforts to teen parents on welfare. States were required to implement the Act by Oct. 1, 1990. The booklet was designed to assist those who serve teen parents on how to become involved both in planning and providing services.Children's Defense Fund1991Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Sherman, ArlocAuthor Ebb, NancyAuthor

0116_000050_000347Vanishing Dreams: The Growing Economic Plight of America's Young Families938008935Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report provides a new look at a previous report of the same name published in 1988, which showed that young families with children in 1986 were far worse off economically than the previous generation. New data collected shows that young families with children were barely helped at all by the economic growth of the mid-to late 1980s, and that the tiny gains they achieved during this period were more than wiped out in 1990 by the effects of the Recession.Children's Defense Fund1988reportsreformatted digital engtext Johnson, CliffordAuthor Sum, AndrewAuthor Weill, JamesAuthor

0116_000050_000348Vanishing Dreams: The Growing Economic Plight of America's Young Families938008935Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report describes the current status of families headed by persons under the age of 30; compares the economic well-being of the current generation of young families in 1986 with that of the preceding generation in 1973; and analyzes the widening gaps between young families with and without children, between young families headed by persons with the least and most education, and between younger and older families.Children's Defense Fund1992reportsreformatted digital engtext Johnson, CliffordAuthor Sum, AndrewAuthor Weill, JamesAuthor

0116_000050_000349Families Struggling to Make It in the Workforce: A Post Welfare ReportLangston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report is based upon survey forms collected from more than 5,000 families and individuals by some 180 local community agencies participating in the CDF Community Monitoring Project (CMP) in 65 cities located in 16 states between January 1999 and December of 1999. The project was designed to take a closer look at families that had left welfare since 1996 and sought help from these agencies. Most of the agencies that participated in the study provide homeless shelter, emergency food, and other services targeted to the poorest of the poor, making the study a unique look at families who are struggling the hardest in these communities.Children's Defense Fund2000reportsreformatted digital engtext Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)Author

CDF examined programs that treat or serve families struggling with substance abuse, homelessness, domestic violence, and teen parenting. Family care programs were defined as those that allow parents and children to live together in supervised living arrangements for an extended period.Children's Defense Fund1998reportsreformatted digital engtext Allen, MaryLeeAuthor Larson, JamilaAuthor

0116_000050_000354Enforcing Child Support: Are States Doing the Job?Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This CDF report looks at state-by-state child support data to examine the impact of a decade of reform efforts. The report compares data reported by the states to the federal government in FY 1993 and FY 1994 and provides charts for each state to measure progress on key indicators of success for children.Children's Defense Fund1994Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Ebb, NancyAuthor

0116_000050_000355State Child Care Fact Book 1988938008684Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report contains the findings of CDF's sixth annual survey on child care funding and priorities in the states and documents the urgent need for investment in child care to close the gap between the need for and the supply of safe and affordable child care. The report is divided into five sections: Summary of Findings, Child Care and Welfare Reform: New Opportunities for States, Elements of a Child Care Agenda, 1988 State Child Care Developments, and the Appendixes, which include detailed data about Title XX services, expenditures and reimbursement rates, waiting lists for child care by state, and key child care officials and advocacy centers in each state.Children's Defense Fund1988Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Blank, HelenAuthor Savage, JenniferAuthor Wilkins, AmyAuthor

0116_000050_000356Child Care: The States' Response: A Survey of State Child Care Policies 1983-1984Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)CDF surveyed every state in the country in 1983 to gather information on the nature, quality, and extent of child care serv ices being offered under Title XX of the Social Security Act, the Social Services Block Grant. Title XX is the major source of direct federal funding for child care. CDF published the findings in a study entitled Children and Federal Child Care Cuts: A National Survey of the Impact of Federal Title XX Cuts on State Child Care Systemin Sept. 1983. Since that time, we conducted a second study and updated the findings. This report represents the results of that survey and an agenda that must be implemented if we are to meet the needs of our children and families.Children's Defense Fund1984Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Blank, HelenAuthor

0116_000050_000357Child Poverty Data from 1990 CensusLangston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report analyzes figures made public by the US Census Bureau. The Census Bureau's definition of "poverty" and the definition of "children" are given in the report. Data is presented by state for 1979 and 1989 including percentage change in rank. City poverty data for African American and Latino youth is also included in the report as well as the top 20 cities with the highest child poverty rates in 1989.Children's Defense Fund1992Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)Author

It focuses on conducting child care market rate surveys and establishing reimbursement policies that can support quality child care. The "Market Rates" concept is explained as well as the "Market Driven" approach to the purchase of publicly funded child care services as included in federal initiatives.Children's Defense Fund1994Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Stoney, LouiseAuthor

0116_000050_000360The Health of America's Children: Maternal and Child Health Data Book938008692Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report traces prenatal care utilization and other key maternal and child health indicators over time and assesses the nation's failure to ensure adequate care to its most vulnerable citizens. The book examines national, state, and large city infant mortality rates; compares U.S. infant mortality rates with those of other coutries; and assesses American children's and pregnant women's access to health care, patterns of childbearing among teenagers and unmarried women, private insurance coverage for children and pregnant women, and the surgeon general's 1990 Objectives on seven key health indicators.Children's Defense Fund1988Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Hughes, DanaAuthor Johnson, KayAuthorRosenbaum, SaraAuthor Butler, ElizabethAuthor Simons, JanetAuthorUnited States Child health services Maternal health services Maternal and infant welfare Infants--Mortality Adolescent Pregnancy Prevention Prenatal Care Program and CDF University of Tennessee, Knoxville. 0116_000050_000361The Health of America's Southern Children: Maternal and Child Health Data Book - Special Edition938008722Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report documents the progress made and the progress urgently needed now to improve maternal and child health care in the southern states, to save southern infants' and children's lives and health, and to save taxpayer dollars through preventive health care and improved family support. The report brings together a great wealth of information about maternal and child health programs, as well as key health status and health care utilization stats. Key facts on such topics as infant mortality, low birthweight, prenatal care, and childhood mortality are covered, and the presentation of state-by-state fact sheets help provide a summary of health and program statistics.Children's Defense Fund1989reportsreformatted digital engtext Whitfill, AileenAuthor Liu, JosephAuthorJohnson, KayAuthor
Southern States Child health services Maternal health services University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Libraries <accessCondition type="use and reproduction" xlink:href="http://rightsstatements.org/vocab/InC-NC/1.0/>In Copyright - Non-Commercial Use Permitted
0116_000050_000362Managed Care and Children's Health: An Analysis of Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, and Treatment Services under State Medicaid Managed Care ContractsLangston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report examines the intent to which state Medicaid agencies incorporate the various requirements of the EPSDT (Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, and Treatment) Program into contracts with managed care plans. These contracts are the principle document signifying the plans' service obligations. Because EPSDT encompasses such a broad range of services, this report helps make clear which coverage, service, or administrative requirements remain the responsibility of the state agency and out-of-plan providers and which become the duty of managed care plans.Children's Defense Fund1995Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Rivera, LourdesAuthor Regan, CarolAuthor Rosenbaum, SaraAuthor

0116_000050_000364Summary of the New Welfare Legislation (Public Law 104-193)Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report is a summary of the New Welfare Legislation {P.L. 104-193, the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996}, which was passed by Congress and signed into law by President Bill Clinton on Aug. 22, 1996. This new law slashed help for children and families in a broad range of safety net programs. Cuts in federal funds for these programs totaled $54 billion over six years. The New Federal Welfare Law limited welfare to a maximum of five years, restricted food stamp distribution, cut assistance to as many as 300,000 children with disabilities, made it possible to track parents who owed child support payments, and outlined what health benefits children and families could receive.Children's Defense Fund1996Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext
United States Public welfare Child welfare United States. Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Libraries <accessCondition type="use and reproduction" xlink:href="http://rightsstatements.org/vocab/InC-NC/1.0/>In Copyright - Non-Commercial Use Permitted
0116_000050_000365The Nation's Investment in Children: An Analysis of the President's FY 1992 Budget ProposalsLangston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report contains detailed information about the Bush Administration's FY 1992 Budget that affected 12.6 million poor children in our country. Infant mortality rates, homeless children and families, the foster care system, and failing schools are some of the areas covered in the report. Charts and graphs are used throughout the report to highlight the inadequate budget allocations that resulted in little to no improvement to the condition of poor children and families in the US.Children's Defense Fund1991reportsreformatted digital engtext Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)Author
United States Child welfare Federal aid to child welfare Poor children University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Libraries <accessCondition type="use and reproduction" xlink:href="http://rightsstatements.org/vocab/InC-NC/1.0/>In Copyright - Non-Commercial Use Permitted
0116_000050_000366What You Need to Know and Do to Truly Leave No Child BehindLangston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This action guide describes how the Bush budget brings good news to the rich, bad news to the poor, defies the prophets and the gospels, and mocks American values of fair play and opportunity. It analyzes the Bush administration's budget war on children and steps you can take to protect and invest rather than hurt children. Part I outlines our investment choices as a nation. Part II outlines the key provisions of the comprehensive Dodd-Miller Act to Leave No Child Behind (which the CDF Action Council supports), important victories to date, and how it differs from the Bush administration's No Child Left Behind Act. Part III describes the gap between the Bush administration's compassionate words and uncompassionate deeds for children. Part IV provides state-by-state tables on child poverty, child health coverage, and state spending per public school pupil and per priosoner. The Appendix lists a few resources to help you and key action dates.Children's Defense Fund2003reportsreformatted digital engtext Children's Defense Fund (U.S.). Action CouncilAuthor
United States Child welfare Education, Elementary Project Head Start (U.S.) University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Libraries <accessCondition type="use and reproduction" xlink:href="http://rightsstatements.org/vocab/InC-NC/1.0/>In Copyright - Non-Commercial Use Permitted
0116_000050_000367A Call for Action to Make Our Nation Safe for Children: A Briefing Book on the Status of American Children in 1988Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This briefing book is designed for all those in public life, child advocates, community activists, professionals, policy makers, parents, citizens, members of the media, and political leaders of all parties seeking office in 1988 and their staffs. Its purpose is to ensure basic social literacy among the media, citizens, and candidates for public office about the facts and needed remedies for American children and families and about the high economic and social costs of child neglect to every American. Part 1 lays out key facts in important areas affecting children and families, the gap in current successful programs for children and families, and the cost-effectiveness of preventive investment. Part 2 includes key charts on the status of families and children with state-by-state date. Part 3 shows how America compares to other nations in protecting its children. The appendix outlines the history of important federal investments in children and youths and summarizes the polls that indicate that helping children in 1988 is not only a moral and practical imperative but is also good politics.Children's Defense Fund1988Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)Author

0116_000050_000368Your Family's Rights under the New Fair Housing Law938008749Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This booklet introduces the reader to the Fair Housing Amendment Act of 1988, passed by Congress making it unlawful to discriminate against families with children and people with disabilities. The law was a strong response to reports across the country that families with children are very often victims of housing discfrimination. The booklet introduces the reader to the new law and helps the reader determine if he or she has been unfairly denied housing because of their children.Children's Defense Fund1989Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)Author

The first publication,New Partnerships: Education's Stake in the Family Support Act of 1988, was aimed at state and local education and human services policy makers, administrators, and practitioners and explored the potential for collaboration among education and welkfare agencies in the implementation of the new law. This monoigraph looks at why local schools, health and welfare agencies, youth services agencies, community-based organizations, and others must join forces on behalf of children and families, and offers guidance based on emerging experience about how they can move forward together. The document should be viewed as a work in progress because of the uncertainty about the outcome of federal proposals. Transitional child care (TCC) is a new federal child care program that every state must have implemented by April 1, 1990. 0116_000050_000407The Health of America's Black ChildrenLangston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report presents startling statistics on the health of America's Black Children. Infant mortality, maternal mortality, low birthweight, prenatal care, immunization, AIDS, health insurance, drugs, tobacco, alcohol, and violence are a few of the topics explored as they relate to the Black child. Preventive measures and steps that need to be taken to eliminate the gap found in Black children's health issues are explored.Children's Defense Fund1988Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Hughes, DanaAuthor Butler, ElizabethAuthor Meehan, MarshaAuthor

The report also presents information on grants and assists states in providing child care for all families - The New Child Care Development Block Grant, part of the New Welfare Act and the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Block Grant (TANF), which replaced Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC). Transitional Child Care and At-Risk Child Care are also discussed.Children's Defense Fund1997Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Blank, HelenAuthor

0116_000050_000409Locked Doors: States Struggling to Meet the Child Care Needs of Low-Income FamiliesLangston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report presents the findings from a 50-state survey of state child care administrators, conducted by CDF by phone interview during Dec. 1997 to Jan. of 1998. The data collected from these interviews were verified with each administrator after they were collected. The findings of the report indicate that many families face a series of locked doors. Many are not even eligible for help due to low state eligibility cutoffs for child care assistance. Many who are eligible for assistance cannot get it due to waiting lists or are turned away due to inadequate funds. Enormous gaps still remain in our efforts to help low income families work and take care of their children.Children's Defense Fund1998Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Adams, GinaAuthor Schulman, KarenAuthor Ebb, NancyAuthor

0116_000050_000416Rescuing the American Dream: Halting the Economic Freefall of Today's Young Families with Children1881985148Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report details the deep economic losses among young families with children and warns of troubling consequences from these losses, for young and old Americans alike. The report reveals that even though America is richer today than ever before, it does not ensure that families have adequate wages and income, education, training, health care, child care, and affordable housing. Many graphs are used to illustrate issues such as poverty rates of children by age and employment of family head, median family income by age of family head and presence of children, change in median income by age of family and presence of children, and homeownership rates of families with children by age of household head.Children's Defense Fund1997reportsreformatted digital engtext Sherman, ArlocAuthor

0116_000050_000421State Investments in Child Care and Early Childhood EducationLangston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)This report is one in a series of studies by the Children's Defense Fund examining state policies and practices in child care and early childhood education. It focuses on state expenditures on programs that help low-income families purchase child care, provide preschool education services to children, or provide child care assistance to special groups of families (such as teen parents, migrant or refugee families, or families whose children are at risk of abuse or neglect). Only those programs where the state had discretion over the funding and policies were included--consequently these data truly reflect the level of state commitment to meeting the needs of families and children for child care assistance.Children's Defense Fund1992reportsreformatted digital engtext Adams, GinaAuthor Sandfort, JodiAuthor

The purpose of the book is to provide all concerned persons with detailed but understandable information about where our largest cities, states, and the nation stand on matters involving the health of pregnant women and infants. Part One presents a wide variety of national statistics about mothers and infants and charts the nation's progress toward improving their health. Part Two contains a detailed series of data tables on state health statistics. Part Three presents vital statistics for the United States in 1982.Children's Defense Fund1985Children's Defense Fund (U.S.)reportsreformatted digital engtext Johnson, KayAuthor Rosenbaum, SaraAuthorSimons, JanetAuthor

0116_000050_000423Congressional Workbook - Basic Process and Issue PrimerLangston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)The goal of this document is to "arm" children's advocates with the basics to help ignite those who care about investments on behalf of children and to educate those who say they are "for" children. This document includes the basics about the budget and appropriations process, the federal budget surplus, how a bill becomes a law, the basics of key leading children's programs, the Committees and Subcommittees in the House and Senate that work on children's issues, key lists of House and Senate leadership, the Congressional schedule, a legislative glossary, and important Web sites for members of Congress and Federal agencies.Children's Defense Fund1999reportsreformatted digital engtext Allen, MaryLeeAuthor Andrejack, KateAuthor Neelum, AryaAuthor
